data.text: Tire Pressure of Tubeless Tires on Pavement

When riding pavement only, should gravel tires still go no where near max psi? I know it’s supposed to be lower to conform to rocks and act as a suspension but is it the same idea for smooth pavement? Should I just increase psi a bit?
Definitely
data.author: Charles Kempf

data.text: If I'm using my gravel bike on just pavement I'll crank the psi in the tires up - so much more zoomy!
data.author: Alex Mickelson

data.text: do you go max?
data.author: Steven Kazavchinski

data.text: if I'm just on pavement, yeah! Or close, at least. Like at least 80% I do use tubes though (not sure if that changes anything if tubeless). I think it's all preference though - more maxed tires will be harder and faster, less full is softer, but slower. It's not that one is right or wrong - just preference!
data.author: Alex Mickelson

data.text: Vincent Wheels the flatter the tire, the more rolling resistance.
data.author: Logan LB

data.text: Vincent Wheels Fair! Thanks for the article! I guess for me it is more about the "feeling" fast. When I have been on gravel or singletrack and the tires are down at around 25ish, then I pump em up to about 70 and take off down the street it FEELS way faster and more nimble and "zoomy", which I really enjoy! It's all preference; I'll keep the speed thing in mind next time though
data.author: Alex Mickelson

data.text: , no - it's a trade-off with energy wasted bouncing. See the articles.
data.author: Frederick Hoefert

data.text: nope
data.author: Rodd Heino

data.text: also keep in mind that the vibration over time is less efficient and more tiring. Limiting factor on long rides is often neck,shoulders back and bum. Whatever you can do to minimize vibration the better.
data.author: Rodd Heino

data.text: yep. Simple physics.
data.author: Logan LB

data.text: I get that. Compare the rolling speed of an over inflated tire and a tire going flat. Which rolls further?
data.author: Logan LB

data.text: Guys guys guys
data.author: Steven Kazavchinski

data.text:
you assume that rolling resistance is a function of surface area of the tire on the ground. You'd be incorrect. Rolling resistance has very little to do with how much tire is on the ground. I encourage you to learn more about this as it makes the biggest difference in both comfort and speed. What makes a fast tire is a supple tire. This interview with Josh Poertner, is very informative. Josh was previously the Technical director at Zipp and has worked with pro cycling teams extensively. Your tires are lying to you. https://youtu.be/asEYkpW0vwQ
Your TIRES are LYING to YOU!
youtube.com
data.author: Rodd Heino

data.text: , soft ≠ flat.
data.author: Frederick Hoefert

data.text: Tarmac requires slightly higher pressure than offroad depending on the tire type.
data.author: Xaver von Treyer

data.text: Max? Definitely not. Use the Silca professional calculator. You can select pavement for your riding preference
data.author: Ryan McClure

data.text: If I am going to be on only pavement I up the pressure while still keeping the ride comfortable.
data.author: John Shoemaker

data.text: Only if the pavement is flawless
data.author: Garrett Hudson

data.text: Which is never is unless you’re indoors on a velodrome.
data.author: Cory Anderson

data.text:
https://silca.cc/pages/sppc-form
SILCA Professional Tire Pressure Calculator
silca.cc
data.author: David R Pletcher

data.text: I ride near max psi on pavement.
data.author: P.W. Poubelle

data.text: I'm a chubster on 700x37 tires. I ride my smooth packed towpaths around 35ish. I boop up to the mid 40s for some road time
data.author: Jon Love

data.text: I ride on Schwalbe 29x2.35 Big Apples, as "most surfaces" tires. Max psi rating is 55psi; I usually ride 50psi on pavement, a bit lower off-road (mostly rock dust, fine gravel and hard pack). Also, I'm a big guy who rides this one bike "everywhere," road and trail. The tires are pretty slick, and the higher pressure works better for me on pavement. Last summer, I was on a trail in Algonquin Provincial Park, Ontario Canada, that was pretty chunky in spots (softball-sized embedded stones in dirt and gravel), and I was about 45psi at the time. I was more worried about my wheels than my tires.
data.author: Mike Bauer

data.text: I was able to fine tune by the sound of the tires. WTB Nano has nobby sides but the middle rides like a ridge. On smooth pavement I increase until I no longer hear the nobby sides on the pavement. There is a very distinct difference in sound and a slight difference in feel when they get where I want them for pavement.
data.author: Cindy Nation

data.text: I usually bump up 5psi for a mostly road day.
data.author: Michael Troy

data.text: Near max depends on your weight though
data.author: Jonathan Smith

data.text: Just do what feels good.
data.author: Peter Moorman

data.text:
Check this website out… it will help you dial in your psi for the worst terrain you will ride any given day https://silca.cc/pages/sppc-form
SILCA Professional Tire Pressure Calculator
silca.cc
data.author: Rich Speidel

data.text: I’m lazy. Same pressure off and on road
data.author: Ernie Villalon

data.text: I am riding at 60-70 for a 500 mile across state run at the moment on tarmac
data.author: Josh Weiser

data.text: I have a 700x46 front and 700x38 rear. On singletrack I’m between 20-30 psi but on pavement typically 50 psi front and 60 psi rear. Definitely faster at higher psi, but these are fairly smooth surfaces on bumpy pavement you may still want to drop pressure some to take out the chop.
data.author: Jonathan Thornburg

data.text: I do.
data.author: Wai Sing Lee

data.text: I have a set of continental tires in 32mm I use if I am going for a ride with the group of triathletes.
data.author: Jon Bryant

data.text: All of my riding includes both road and off-road riding. I'm 13st 7lbs. Run 32psi in my front 700x40 Run 36psi in my rear 700x42
data.author: Steven Darwick
